abstracts.cdata!:
This is an update of an environmental
            impact assessment (EIA) of the Xiaolangdi Multipurpose Dam
            (XLD) Project, Stage II. The project's overall plan and
            its components remain essentially unchanged from that
            described in the 1993 EA (report no. E30). The XLD project
            is designed to protect downstream population settlements,
            farms, and infrastructure from the hazards of disastrous
            floods; and to achieve a major expansion in downstream
            irrigation, providing sufficient electric power and water
            supply to support urbanization/industrialization, to enhance
            estuarine ecology, and to expand aquaculture. The
            environmental protection components include the relics
            protection program; the disease control and protection
            program; dam stability against earthquake hazards; air,
            water, and land quality impacts; and impacts on natural
            vegetation and animals, on rare and commercial species, and
            on villages around the sites. A detailed archeological
            exploration, classification, and salvage program has been
            undertaken to locate, recover, and protect important
            underground and surface relics and cultural treasures in the
            area to be inundated. After excavation, objects with value,
            like earthware, stoneware, etc. will be repaired and stored
            in museums. The rest, like tomb, ash pit, etc., will be
            recorded in writing and photographed for further study.
            According to the evaluation, the main components of objects
            with historical values will be removed and relocated, if
            possible, and those which cannot be removed, will be sampled
            and recorded. A number of serious public health concerns,
            especially communicable diseases, pose significant problems
            if protective measures are not taken. The project could
            significantly increase the hazards of malaria, encephalitis,
            hemorrhagic fever, and enteric diseases. Measures for
            control of mosquito vector diseases in the construction zone
            include: medical screening of all workers; periodic spraying
            of all buildings in construction work areas and camps; and
            periodic monitoring of pertinent mosquito species larvae.
            The hemorrhagic fever control program is based on
            controlling mice and rat density; and includes medical
            screening examinations and annual examinations for all
            construction workers. The mitigation program for enteric and
            other disease control in the construction zone involves
            maintaining sanitary conditions in the construction work and
            living areas, including safe water supply and adequate
            liquid and solid waste management, and air pollution
            controls. To address dam safety in the event of earthquakes,
            a special seismoscopic network is needed to carry out
            seismic monitoring, allow information feedback, and provide
            proper earthquake prediction. The assessment determines that
            either minimally negative or -actually- positive effects
            will result from the Yellow River's lower flows and
            less turbid water for the following: freshwater fishery,
            water quality, land accretion, landslides, reservoir
            seepage, development of the wetlands, and changes in
            biodiversity. Reservoir formation will inundate sizable
            deposits of mineral resources, but the only potentially
            significant loss would be of coal; however, because the coal
            lies beneath impermeable shale strata, some mining of it
            will remain feasible after inundation. Among the number of
            rare and protected species in the reservoir and in the
            surrounding area, only waterfowl will be directly affected,
            their populations possibly increasing. A properly planned
            flood control system includes not only constructing and
            operating physical flood control works, but also flood
            forecasting and an emergency response system. Finally, a
            detailed resettlement plan is elaborated.
